bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, November 26, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses the Cornwell yellow fever painting and the response to it in the U.S. Hench wishes that she had uncovered more material from her father's papers, but he thanks her nonetheless for providing information about Agramonte's life in New Orleans and details of his death.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, November 26, 1941
div1.opener:
November 26, 1941
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez-Leon
Calle 15 No. 311
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Senora Rodriguez-Leon:
div1.p:
At last the reprints of my Hygeia article have come and I am sending you
12 copies. If you want more do not hesitate to let me know; thanks to Wyeth and Co.,
I have an ample supply. I assume that Mr. Kellogg has sent you one or more of the
large copies of the painting. He assured me he was going to and I know he will be
delighted to let you have all you wish. The painting has aroused much favorable
comment in the United States and you must be gratified I am sure to see your father
assuming therein his rightful place. We do so hope that your countrymen will see in
the painting a real, honest, and sincere attempt to give to Dr. Finlay his due credit.

I have been too busy with my medical work the past two months to do much on
the yellow fever story but now I have more leisure and am back at it again. I hope to
visit Washington in January to see if I can find the old records in the Surgeon General's
office. I shall also try to find the records of your father's goings and comings,
absences, etc. so as to refute the idea that he was not in Havana when Lazear died,
or, if he was absent we can find out why, etc. not that his absence should permit one
to question his motives or right to be absent. In January I go to Washington to speak
at a medical meeting (on arthritis) and in March I hope to go with Mrs. Hench to Cali-
fornia on vacation during which we hope to see Mrs. Lazear and Gen. Truby. Gen. Truby's
manuscript of his experiences in Cuba with Reed, etc. is about ready for publication.
In several places he seems uncertain as to your father's whereabouts and work and I
have been very careful to call his attention repeatedly to your father's written state-
ments. I sent him a copy of your father's letter to Hemmeter, etc. so that your father's
position would be clear to him. But if you can come across any data, letters, diary,
etc. that would be helpful I think it might cause Gen. Truby to get the picture more
accurately.

I am “sick” to think you found so little in the boxes at the farm. Perhaps
you will still come across the mislaid data. You say you found many more reprints.
I wonder if you found any of the original first 3 or 4 reprints of the whole Board.
I have been unable to get these original copies and if you ever find duplicates I
would be more than pleased to receive what you can spare me.

You are always such a busy person--it seems to me you crowd three or four
lives into one, being a mother, wife, teacher and degree-candidate. How can you do
so much? I send you my best wishes for a rapid and successful completion of your
Ph. D. work.

Mrs. Hench and I had a very nice, if hasty, visit to Pensacola and New
Orleans. I had a very agreeable morning with Mr. William Postell, librarian at the
Agramonte Memorial Library. He showed me your father's books and all the papers you
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez-Leon
- 2 -
November 26, 1941
left there. I went over all the latter most carefully and thinking you might like
it, I made a list of the data they have, which list I enclose. Unfortunately,
there was little or no data there which cleared up any of the holes in the story
or the controversies we are trying to straighten out. In particular Mr. Postell
told me of his careful but vain search through all your father's books and papers
hunting for the European History Book signed by Marti. Certainly I found nothing
in the papers along that line. Mr. Postell is very proud of the data of your father's
which they have and would be glad indeed to have more (In that he and I are certainly
alike:)

I am enclosing a couple bookplates from the library. The building shown
is the Medical Center and the library is on one of the lower floors. In the hall out-
side the library is a fine bas-relief in stone and metal representing, rather alle-
gorically, the four members of the board and the tropics before and after the conquest
of yellow fever. I tried to get a photo of it but none were available. I'll keep
trying.

Mrs. Hench and I enjoyed meeting Dr. and Mrs. Tripoli. Knowing he was a
friend of your father I assumed he was his contemporary in age and was much surprised
to meet a young man about my own age (or even less:) We had a very pleasant dinner
with them. I was so interested to hear from him of your father's life in New Orleans
and of the details of his death. I hope you will not feel that I intruded in a very
personal matter but I saw that you and your father have real friends in New Orleans
and when the matter of your father's death was mentioned I recalled a passing remark
you had made to me some time ago (in your letter of October 10, 1940) to the effect
that you wished that sometime your father could rest again in Cuban (home) soil. I
mentioned that wish to Dr. Tripoli, and I do believe that if it is still your wish,
something could be done about it by your friends in New Orleans and elsewhere.
Please write me and assure me that I have not been indelicate in this matter and tell
me what your wishes are. In admiration of your father and his family I would be only
too glad to be one of the instruments to accomplish your desire. If I have intruded
unwisely into a very personal matter please forgive me and know that my motives were
sympathetic.

Give our kindest regards to your husband and we do hope we can visit our
good friends in Havana in the not too distant future.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
